API Reference

There are two main types of objects: AMMs and Trading Curves

AMMs

AMM base type

The following is the supertype of all AMMs.

ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.AMM — Type

AMM base interface. An AMM has parameters applied but has not been initialized at a given liquidity. Corresponds to the "CFMM" concept in the liquidity density paper.

TODO describe expected interface. Probably in a separate docs page.

source

Base AMMs

ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.CPMM — Type
CPMM()

Constant-product AMM.

\[x \cdot y = L^2\]

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.C2LP — Type
C2LP(alpha, beta)

Gyroscope 2CLP, aka concentrated constant-product, aka a single Uniswap v3 bracket.

\[(x + a) \cdot (y + b) = L^2\]

where $a = l / \sqrt{\beta}$ and $b = l \cdot \sqrt{\alpha}$.

See also the Gyroscope docs.

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.ECLP — Type
ECLP(alpha, beta, q, lambda)

Gyroscope Elliptic Concentrated Liquidity Pool

Here:

  • alpha and beta are the price range
  • q is the target price of concentration
  • lambda >= 1 is the amplification factor

See the Gyroscope docs.

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.StableSwap — Type
StableSwap(A)

StableSwap curve.

Here A is the amplification factor.

Note: Only 2 assets are supported right now and also assumed.

Note: The StableSwap paper has an inconsistency vs Curve's (and most) implementations in its treatment of the amplification parameter A. In this library, all user-facing operations (construction and display) use the "code form". Internally, we use the "math form".

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.WeightedPool — Type
WeightedPool(delta)

A weighted product pool (i.e., Balancer's weighted pool).

\[x^\delta * y^{1-\delta} = L \]

The delta parameter describes the weighting towards either asset. delta = 0.5 is equivalent to the CPMM.

delta must be strictly between 0 and 1.

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.CPSMM — Type
CPSMM(delta)

A constant-power-sum-pool (like YieldSpace).

\[x^\delta + y^\delta = L^\delta\]

where $delta$ is strictly between 0 and 1. $delta \to 1$ is the constant-sum AMM and $delta \to 0$ is the CPMM.

source

Transformed AMMs

These take an AMM and yield an AMM that's transformed in some way.

ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.rate_scale — Function
rate_scale(amm, rx, ry) <: AMM
amm |> rate_scale(rx, ry)

A given AMM scaled by the given rates.

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.concentrate — Function
concentrate(amm, alpha, beta) <: AMM
concentrate(tc, alpha, beta)
amm |> concentrate(alpha, beta)
tc |> concentrate(alpha, beta)

Concentrate the given AMM or TradingCurve into a sub-range. This corresponds to (TOOD Theorem ref). (alpha, beta) must be a sub-interval of the price range.

For AMMs, returns a new AMM concentrated into that sub-range.

For trading curves, returns the corresponding curve when preserving the given trading curve's initial price and value. (the initial price must be within the new price bounds)

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.named — Function
named(amm, name) <: AMM
amm |> named(name)

Attach a custom name to an AMM

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.flip — Function
flip(amm)
flip(tc)

Flip the x and y assets.

Flipping an AMM changes what the two assets mean. Flipping a TradingCurve yields the same TradingCurve with the same initial state but with the x and y assets flipped.

source

Shorthands

ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.constant_rate_scaled_eclp — Function
constant_rate_scaled_eclp(alpha, beta, q; q_inner)

Define a rate-scaled ECLP scaled by a constant rate. alpha, beta, and q refer to "outer" prices. The inner parameters will be chosen such that these outer prices are exhibited, and the inner q is 1.0. Set q_inner to change that. This can be used to adjust the peak (since it's not exactly at q, only approximately). lam always refers to the inner curve.

source

Querying AMMs

AMMs themselves only store some basic information.

ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.alphabeta — Function
alpha, beta = alphabeta(amm)
alpha, beta = alphabeta(tc)

The lower and upper end of the price range, or (0.0, Inf).

Required for AMMs with concentrated price range.

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.kind_name — Function
kind_name(amm)
kind_name(tc)

Name of the AMM type (without parameters)

Optional.

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.short_str — Function
short_str(amm; as_bp::Bool)
short_str(tc; as_bp::Bool)

Short description of the AMM with parameters. If as_bp=true, render all prices in bp.

Optional, rarely needs an overload

source

Trading Curves

ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.TradingCurve — Type

A trading curve. It is expected that this has a field .common of type TCCommon.

SOMEDAY that's kinda bad actually.

source

Creating Trading Curves from AMMs

Given an AMM and parameters defining a starting point / invariant, one can create a TradingCurve from an AMM like so:

ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.tc_v_p — Function
tc_v_p(amm::AMM, v, p)

Trading curve of an AMM at the given portfolio value v and price p.

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.tc_l_p — Function
tc_l_p(amm::AMM, l, p)

Trading curve of an AMM at the given invariant l and price p

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.tc_t — Function
tc_t(amm::AMM, t) <: TradingCurve

Trading curve of an AMM at the given balances t.

source

Querying Trading Curves

With a trading curve constructed, we can query the curve in various ways.

ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.TCCommon — Type

Common fields for trading curves. Every TradingCurve has a .common member of this type.

SOMEDAY that's not a good design actually.

Fields:

  • amm - The AMM of the trading curve
  • l - The invariant
  • t_init - Initial balances
  • p_init - Initial price
source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.y_x — Function
y_x(tc, x)

y balance given the x balance.

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.x_y — Function
x_y(tc, y)

x balance given the y balance.

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.t_p — Function
t_p(tc::TradingCurve, p)

Balances at given price p

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.t_plus — Function
x_plus, y_plus = t_plus(tc)

Maximal x and and y values along the trading curve. Inf if none, respectively.

TODO refactor: this gives an error if not implemented but alphabeta defaults to (0, Inf). Inconsistent. This behavior is prob better.

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.v_init — Function
v_init(common::TCCommon)
v_init(tc)

Portfolio value / TVL denominated in y asset units, at pool initialization

source

Helpers

ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.union_priceset — Function
union_priceset(amms) :: Vector{Tuple{Float64,Float64}}
union_priceset(tcs)

Return the union of the price sets of a set of AMMs as a minimal union of intervals. Can be used with both AMMs and TCs.

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.intersect_priceset — Function
intersect_priceset(amms) :: Union{Nothing,Tuple{Float64,Float64}}
intersect_priceset(tcs)

Return the intersection of the price sets of a set of AMMs. Returns Nothing if the AMMs don't intersect. Can be used with both AMMs and TCs.

source

Querying Liquidity Density

ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.dydp_p — Function
dydp_p(tc, p)

Absolute liquidity density at the given price

NOTE: This is only defined for AMMs where this is fast to compute. Don't use this for plotting; instead, use sample_dydp_p().

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.dydlogp_p — Function
dydlogp_p(tc, p)

Relative liquidity density at the given price

NOTE: This is only defined for AMMs where this is fast to compute. Don't use this for plotting; instead, use sample_dydlogp_p().

source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.dydp_max — Function
dydp_max(tc; plim=(0.0, Inf)) :: Tuple{Float64,Float64}

(price, value) of the maximal value of dydp (absolute liquidity density), optionally within the interval plim. If plim is not a subset of the price set, the intersection is taken.

Keyword parameters

  • plim: If given, limit to that range. must be given for trading curves with infinite price range.
  • unit: Unit of price change. The default is 1.0 = ±1.
  • pathological: If true, we include pathological limit behavior for some AMMs (e.g., StableSwap's infinite LD if plim includes 0.0). Otherwise, these points are ignored.
source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.dydlogp_max — Function
dydlogp_max(tc::TradingCurve; plim=(0.0, Inf)) :: Tuple{Float64,Float64}

(price, value) of the value of dydlogp (relative liquidity density), optionally within the interval plim. If plim is not a subset of the price set, the intersection is taken.

Keyword parameters

  • plim: If given, limit to that range. must be given for trading curves with infinite price range.
  • unit: Unit of price change. The default is ±1%.
  • pathological: If true, we include pathological limit behavior for some AMMs (e.g., StableSwap's infinite LD if plim includes 0.0). Otherwise, these points are ignored.
source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.sample_dydp_p — Function
sample_dydp_p(tc)

Sample (p, dydp) points (absolute LD curve) from the given TradingCurve. Returns a vector of pairs.

Keyword parameters

  • plim: If given, limit to that range. must be given for trading curves with infinite price range.
  • unit: Unit of price change. The default is 1.0 = ±1.
source
ConstantFunctionMarketMakers.sample_dydlogp_p — Function
sample_dydlogp_p(tc)

Sample (p, dydlogp) points (relative LD curve) from the given TradingCurve. Returns a vector of pairs.

Keyword parameters

  • plim: If given, limit to that range. must be given for trading curves with infinite price range.
  • unit: Unit of price change. The default is 0.01 = ±1%.
source
